Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Situation2: A routine service is held, and attendance numbers are usually sufficient even if one person is absent.
Story: The phone in my hand felt heavier than usual as I glanced at the clock—just an hour left before the end of the quarter. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We need every sale to hit our target, or we all lose out.” I could hear the buzz of my coworkers dialing, voices rising with urgency. My own numbers were just shy of the mark. I knew if I stayed, I could help push us over the line. But tonight was also the weekly synagogue service. My father had called earlier, reminding me gently, “It’s important to show up, even when it’s routine. Community matters.” I pictured the familiar faces, the warmth of shared prayers, the sense of belonging. Yet, I also felt the weight of my team’s expectations, the pressure to perform, the fear of letting everyone down. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between dialing another number and grabbing my coat for the walk to synagogue, caught in the tightening grip of two worlds that suddenly felt impossibly far apart.
